title: How to Cook a Potato in the Microwave

steps.headline: Select and clean the potato.
steps.description: For best results, select a Russet potato to bake in the microwave. Scrub the potato to remove all dirt since the skin will be left on for cooking. Rinse the potato thoroughly and dry. Use a paring knife to remove blemishes from the potato.

steps.headline: Poke holes.
steps.description: Poke 4-5 holes on each side of the potato using a fork. These holes will allow steam to escape during cooking and prevent the potato from exploding in the microwave. Place the potato in a microwave-safe plate or dish.

steps.headline: Microwave the potato for three minutes.
steps.description: Microwave the potato on full power for three minutes. Stop the microwave and remove the potato to check. A single potato should take just over five minutes to cook, but it is better to err on the side of caution to avoid overcooking it. If you opt for a potato other than Russet, alter the cooking time accordingly (less for a smaller potato and more for larger potato).

steps.headline: Test its readiness.
steps.description: Using an oven mitt or kitchen towel, gently squeeze the sides of the potato. If the potato is tender enough to give under the pressure and for the skin to break and open up, it is done. If the potato is still firm, place it back in the microwave and check it again after another minute of cooking.

steps.headline: Garnish the potato.
steps.description:
Once its done, slice open the top of your baked potato with a sharp knife. Place a folded paper towel over the cut and use your other hand to push down on it to open the potato. Fluff out the inside of the potato with a fork and add toppings such as:
Sour cream
Chives
Crumbled bacon
Shredded cheese
Chili
Ground beef

steps.headline: Choose a Russet or Yukon Gold potato.
steps.description: Choose a medium to large sized potato, preferably a Russet or Yukon Gold potato. Scrub and rinse it thoroughly. Dry with a paper towel.

steps.headline: Slice up the potato.
steps.description: Cut the potato up into 1 inch cubes (approximately 2.5 cm). Place potato pieces in a microwave-safe dish. Disperse the potatoes evenly.

steps.headline: Season the potato pieces.
steps.description: Drizzle the potato pieces with olive oil (approximately 0.5 oz. or 1 tbsp.). Sprinkle them with the seasoning of your choice, such as salt and pepper, ranch dressing powder, oregano, or garlic powder. Toss the pieces to coat.

steps.headline: Cover the dish and cook.
steps.description: Cover the dish tightly with a lid or plastic wrap. Do not vent, as the steam trapped inside will cook and brown the potatoes. Microwave on high for 5-10 minutes.

steps.headline: Check to see when they're done.
steps.description: Starting at 5 minutes, check the potato pieces to see if they're cooked by piercing them with a fork. If you can pierce through the potato pieces effortlessly, they are done. If the pieces still seem hard and under-cooked, return them to the microwave and continue checking at 1 minute intervals.

steps.headline: Scrub, wash and dry a large potato.
steps.description: Wash and dry a large potato, making sure to scrub the skin thoroughly. Place it in a microwaveable dish. Do not peel or pierce the potato. Russet potatoes work best, but other kinds of potatoes with thick skin are also good option (e.g. Yukon Gold, sweet potatoes).

steps.headline: Cover and cook.
steps.description: Cover the dish with plastic wrap, leaving a corner open. Microwave on high for 5 minutes. Remove, uncover, and check the potato to see if it's cooked. If not, continue microwaving for another minute and check again.

steps.headline: Peel the potato.
steps.description: Remove the potato from the microwave-safe dish with an oven mitt or kitchen tongs. Run it under cold water for 15 seconds to cool. Make a cut on the side of the potato and slowly remove the skin entirely.

steps.headline: Mash the potato.
steps.description: Place potato in a bowl and add a half cup (4 oz.) of milk, half cup (4 oz.) or sour cream or plain yogurt, and one tbsp. (0.5 oz.) of butter. Mash the potato using a masher or large fork, continuing until smooth. Add salt and pepper to taste.
